teaching.course: Climate II: Coupled Earth System Dynamics
teaching.description: This course is a graduate-level synthesis of how individual components come together and interact to form the Earth's climate system. In 2025, my co-instructor and I were tasked with reimagining this course from the ground up, as it had not been taught at Princeton University for several years. The course is now centered on using a hierarchy of models, ranging from idealized, theoretical representations of the Earth system to fully coupled, comprehensive numerical climate models, to illustrate the core concepts in the course.
highlights: Uses hierarchy of models from idealized to fully coupled comprehensive climate models
Spans atmospheric and ocean dynamics, cryospheric processes, and land surface interactions
Tailored to each student's research and career trajectory

teaching.description: This is the introductory course in the meteorology program. It is a core requirement for students majoring in meteorology, but the course also fulfills the natural science requirement for most Rutgers students. It is a large lecture course that attracts between 60 and 120 students representing a diverse cross-section of majors. I incorporate a real-time weather discussion based on conditions around the state, the nation, and the world to help students relate the concepts learned in the classroom to current events.
highlights: Real-time weather discussions connecting concepts to current events
Balances quantitative rigor for majors with conceptual learning for non-majors
Cultivates curiosity for atmosphere, weather, and the world

teaching.description: Graduate-level course covering the dynamics of the Earth's climate system, including atmospheric and ocean circulation, energy balance, and climate variability.

teaching.course: Guest Lectures: Mass, Momentum, and Energy Transport
teaching.description: Annual guest lectures on climate science applications of transport phenomena, delivered as invited expert talks to undergraduate students.

teachingPhilosophy.overview: We are living in an era of rapid information transformation. Content is more readily available to students, and their attention is continuously being diverted and sought after on multiple platforms and in a variety of formats. In such an environment, my teaching philosophy emphasizes qualities that are uniquely human: curiosity and creativity. As a lecturer at Rutgers University and Princeton University, I have come to understand that research and teaching are deeply intertwined. As we teach, we continuously build curiosity around the topic and grow a deeper understanding of the material.

keyPrinciples.title: Learning Through Questioning
keyPrinciples.description: I take a Socratic approach in guiding students to arrive at their own conclusions. I view myself as a trail guide over the course of a semester, and my role is to lead students on a journey of exploration, encouraging them to notice, question, and explore along the way. I strongly encourage students to seek out evidence to support their views and reinforce what they are learning.

keyPrinciples.title: Inclusive and Adaptable Teaching
keyPrinciples.description: Each student is unique and approaches learning in an individual way. I believe in understanding the diverse learning styles of my students and tailoring my lessons to meet their individual needs. My lectures are filled with analogies, personal anecdotes, and real-world examples, while being rooted in traditional theoretical, mathematical, and physical interpretations.

keyPrinciples.title: Developing Essential Skills
keyPrinciples.description: Students must develop professional skills in addition to subject understanding. I incorporate Python coding exercises into problem sets and emphasize strong communication skills in feedback, helping students grow both technical abilities and scientific knowledge. Developing climate scientists of the future requires instilling both analytical rigor and communication clarity.

keyPrinciples.title: Reaching Beyond the Classroom
keyPrinciples.description: My experience as a research scientist and broadcast meteorologist enables me to demonstrate how classroom concepts translate to real-world skills. I regularly invite alumni to participate in career panels, showcasing how meteorology complements other fields in weather risk analysis, energy forecasting, and science communication.

teachingEvidence.summary: Multiple lines of evidence demonstrate teaching effectiveness. Quantitative metrics from student surveys show average teaching effectiveness (4.72) and course quality (4.64) ratings consistently ranking near the top of a 5-point scale, outperforming departmental means in each semester.

themes.title: Generating Excitement and Inspiration
themes.description: Passion for weather and climate that inspires student interest through weekly weather discussions and sharing current research

themes.title: Teaching with Engagement
themes.description: Interactive discussions, questioning techniques, and constructive dialogue that builds rapport with students

themes.title: Supporting the Student
themes.description: Accessibility, compassion, and flexibility with office hours that promotes individual attention and accommodates diverse needs

themes.title: Reaching Beyond the Classroom
themes.description: Connecting concepts to real-world applications and careers through alumni panels and practical examples
